study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the molecular impact of SAM treatment on colorectal cancer cell lines with distinct genetic features, focusing on cell proliferation, DNA methylation, stability, and gene expression.
results_summary: SAM reduced cell proliferation, induced senescence via S phase arrest, downregulated EMT-related genes, and enhanced DNA repair and genomic stability in SW480 cells, though global DNA methylation changes were not observed.
population_specificity: Colorectal cancer cell lines (HT-29 and SW480)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the combined therapeutic effects of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) and decitabine on breast cancer tumor volume and metastasis in vivo.
results_summary: The combination of SAM and decitabine significantly reduced mammary tumor volume and lung metastasis compared to control and monotherapy groups, with reduced expression of proliferation and angiogenesis markers in primary tumors. Transcriptome and methylome analyses indicated regulation of key cancer-related pathways.
population_specificity: MDA-MB-231 xenograft model of breast cancer (preclinical study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether S-adenosylmethionine (AdoMet) could restore glutathione redox homeostasis and mitigate oxidative stress in the brains of rats with acute liver failure-induced hepatic encephalopathy.
results_summary: AdoMet treatment restored the glutathione (GSH/GSSG) ratio and total glutathione levels in the brains of thioacetamide-treated rats, suggesting its potential therapeutic role in maintaining redox balance and reducing brain damage in hepatic encephalopathy.
population_specificity: Rats with thioacetamide-induced acute liver failure.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intraperitoneal injections, frequency implied but not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anticancer activity of SAM on human gallbladder cancer cells and elucidate its underlying molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: SAM significantly inhibited growth, proliferation, and induced apoptosis and cell cycle arrest in gallbladder cancer cells by suppressing the JAK2/STAT3 pathway, with consistent results in both in vitro and in vivo studies.
population_specificity: Human gallbladder cancer cells (GBC-SD and SGC-996) and xenograft models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy of SAMe versus placebo in unmedicated patients with mild-to-moderate major depressive disorder (MDD).
results_summary: SAMe showed a clinically relevant but statistically non-significant reduction in depression symptoms compared to placebo, with a medium-to-large effect size. It was effective in participants with milder depression severity, but response was not moderated by biomarkers or genetic factors.
population_specificity: Unmedicated patients with DSM-5 diagnosed MDD and mild-to-moderate depressive symptoms (MADRS score 14-25).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the chemo-preventive effect of IFC305 in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is mediated by the induction of SAM biosynthesis and its metabolic flow.
results_summary: IFC305 treatment restored SAM hepatic levels and the methionine cycle, improving transmethylation and transsulfuration activities. It modulated MAT1a and MAT2a levels via post-transcriptional regulation and inhibited the polyamine pathway, likely contributing to its chemo-preventive effect in HCC.
population_specificity: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) models (DEN-induced HCC and CCl4-induced cirrhosis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects and mechanisms of S-adenosylmethionine (SAMe) on hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) cells, focusing on cell cycle regulation and antiproliferative action.
results_summary: SAMe inhibited cell proliferation in HepG2 and AML12 cells, induced S-phase cell cycle arrest, and upregulated cell cycle-related genes (MCM3, MCM4, E2F1). RNA-Seq analysis identified 472 SAMe-related genes, with enrichment in cell cycle pathways.
population_specificity: Human hepatocellular carcinoma cell line HepG2 and mouse hepatocyte AML12.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how differential expression of SAM1 and SAM2 genes affects genome stability and AdoMet levels in yeast.
results_summary: The study found that losses of SAM1 and SAM2 have distinct effects on genome stability, gene expression, and AdoMet levels, influencing the methyl cycle differently. These findings provide insight into how variations in AdoMet synthetase genes contribute to genome instability.
population_specificity: Diploid Saccharomyces cerevisiae (yeast)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether S-adenosylmethionine (SAMe) could alleviate dystonic movements and self-injury behavior in a pediatric patient with Lesch-Nyhan disease (LND).
results_summary: SAMe treatment alleviated generalized dystonia and self-injury behavior in a 6-month-old boy with LND, resolving his self-injury completely when combined with risperidone. It also eliminated inspiratory stridor caused by laryngeal dystonia and reduced respiratory infections.
population_specificity: A 6-month-old boy with Lesch-Nyhan disease (LND).
study_duration: Ongoing (at least 6 months, exact duration unclear)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the early treatment efficacy of S-adenosylmethionine (AdoMet) in adult patients with intrahepatic cholestasis (IHC).
results_summary: AdoMet significantly reduced serum levels of liver enzymes (ALT, AST, ALP, γGT) within 2 weeks in most studies, with further improvements observed in some cases after 4-8 weeks. It also improved symptoms like fatigue and depression, though the timing of these effects varied across studies.
population_specificity: Adult patients with intrahepatic cholestasis (IHC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether disrupting methionine/S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) metabolism could serve as a novel therapeutic approach for MLL-rearranged (MLL-R) leukemia by reducing cellular methylation potential and inhibiting DOT1L function.
results_summary: Disruption of Met/SAM metabolism reduced cellular methylation potential, selectively induced apoptosis in MLL-R leukemia cells, and altered global histone methylation dynamics, including loss of H3K79 methylation. Pharmacologic inhibition of Met/SAM metabolism prolonged survival in a patient-derived MLL-R leukemia xenograft model when combined with chemotherapy.
population_specificity: MLL-R leukemia cell lines (MLL-AF4, MLL-AF6) and patient blasts, compared to BCR-ABL-driven K562 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of S-adenosylmethionine decarboxylase (BvM14-SAMDC) in enhancing salt stress tolerance in plants by regulating polyamine biosynthesis.
results_summary: The study found that overexpression of BvM14-SAMDC in Arabidopsis thaliana increased salt stress tolerance, evidenced by improved root length, fresh weight, chlorophyll content, and antioxidant enzyme activity, while reducing reactive oxygen species (ROS) production.
population_specificity: Sugar beet M14 (BvM14) and transgenic Arabidopsis thaliana plants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) could lessen liver damage induced by regurgitated bile in a rat bile duct ligation (BDL) model.
results_summary: SAM decreased xanthine oxidase activity and thiobarbituric acid reactive substances (TBARS) levels while increasing catalase activity, indicating hepatoprotective effects. It also partially diminished morphological liver damage related to cholestasis, though it did not significantly reduce TNF-α concentration like selenomethionine.
population_specificity: Rats with bile duct ligation-induced liver injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the catalytic mechanisms of MATα2 and how mutations in key residues affect enzymatic activity, as well as the role of MATβ subunits in regulating SAMe production.
results_summary: The study identified critical residues (Gln113, Ser114, Arg264) in MATα2 that influence enzymatic activity, demonstrated the regulatory role of MATβ subunits in restoring activity to mutated enzymes, and explored potential chemical interventions to modulate SAMe levels.
population_specificity: In vitro study focusing on enzyme mechanisms (not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the role of S-adenosylmethionine decarboxylase (SAMDC) in regulating spermidine levels and its impact on cell proliferation and development in Dictyostelium.
results_summary: Overexpression of SAMDC slowed cell proliferation and delayed development, while inhibition of SAMDC with MGBG reduced proliferation but stimulated development. Spermidine levels remained high in SAMDC-overexpressing cells, suggesting its critical role in polyamine homeostasis.
population_specificity: Dictyostelium cells (a model organism, not human)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) could enhance the antitumor effect of gemcitabine (GEM) in pancreatic cancer by inhibiting the JAK2/STAT3 pathway.
results_summary: SAM synergistically enhanced GEM's antitumor effects, significantly inhibiting pancreatic cancer cell growth, proliferation, invasion, and migration while inducing apoptosis. The combination also showed superior tumor suppression in a mouse xenograft model without significant liver or kidney toxicity.
population_specificity: Pancreatic cancer cells (in vitro) and PANC-1 xenograft mouse model (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanisms of S-adenosylmethionine's anti-tumor activity by analyzing its effects on miRNA expression and related biological pathways in breast cancer cells.
results_summary: The study found that S-adenosylmethionine modulated miRNA expression, up-regulating miR-34a and miR-34c while down-regulating miR-486-5p, enhancing apoptosis and autophagy in breast cancer cells. These effects were linked to p53 acetylation and inhibition of SIRT1, HDAC1, and AKT signaling.
population_specificity: MCF-7 and MDA-MB 231 breast cancer cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of MSI-195 (a proprietary formulation of S-adenosylmethionine) as an augmentation therapy for Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) in patients with inadequate response to ongoing antidepressant medication.
results_summary: The study found no overall statistically significant differences between MSI-195 and placebo on depression-rating instruments, but post-hoc analyses showed significant improvement in the first half of the study. MSI-195 was generally safe and well tolerated, with mild gastrointestinal side effects.
population_specificity: Acutely depressed subjects with Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) who had an inadequate response to ongoing antidepressant medication.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how MTHFR genetic variations influence S-adenosylmethionine (adoMet) homeostasis and metabolic fluxes during methotrexate therapy.
results_summary: The study found that MTHFR function significantly affected transmethylation fluxes and adoMet homeostasis in MTX-treated HepG2 cell-lines, but not nucleotide biosyntheses. Lymphoblasts showed altered protein turnover and folate-mediated 1-carbon metabolic fluxes with and without MTX.
population_specificity: Rheumatoid arthritis patients (n=120) and two cell models (HepG2 and Epstein-Barr virus transformed human lymphoblasts).
effective_dosage: Not specified for adoMet; MTX doses varied by genotype (9.8 ± 3.3 mg/week for MTHFR-TT vs. 12.1 ± 3.5 mg/week for MTHFR-CC).
interactions: Methotrexate (MTX) was noted to interact with MTHFR polymorphisms and adoMet synthesis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether S-adenosylmethionine (SAMe) could enhance the efficacy of antidepressants in patients with Major Depressive Disorder (MDD).
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in depression reduction between SAMe and placebo groups, with similar response and remission rates. SAMe showed no effect on secondary outcomes or biomarker responses, and safety was comparable to placebo except for one case of serotonin syndrome-like symptoms.
population_specificity: 107 treatment non-remittent outpatients with DSM-5 diagnosed Major Depressive Disorder (MDD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether SNHG6 lncRNA dysregulation leads to genome-wide hypomethylation by inhibiting S-adenosylmethionine (SAMe) production in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and whether exogenous SAMe could counteract this effect.
results_summary: The study found that SNHG6 lncRNA suppresses SAMe production by inhibiting MAT1A and promoting MAT2A expression, leading to genome-wide hypomethylation in HCC. Exogenous SAMe within a certain concentration range reversed the hypomethylation effect of SNHG6, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for HCC.
population_specificity: Hepatoma cells (in vitro) and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) models (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the toxicity of 3-Deazaneplanocin A (DZNep), an inhibitor of S-adenosylmethionine-dependent methyltransferase, on various tissues, organs, and cognitive functions in mice.
results_summary: Chronic DZNep treatment caused reversible splenomegaly, persistent testis reduction, and erythropoiesis but had no effect on most organs or animal behavior. The study suggests DZNep is promising for cancer treatment with limited irreversible side effects.
population_specificity: Male NMRI mice
effective_dosage: 2 mg/kg, intraperitoneally, three times per week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) in blocking breast cancer development, growth, and metastasis through in vitro and in vivo studies.
results_summary: SAM treatment significantly reduced cell proliferation, invasion, migration, and anchorage-independent growth while increasing apoptosis in vitro, and decreased tumor volume and metastasis in vivo. Gene expression analyses confirmed SAM's ability to downregulate key cancer progression genes.
population_specificity: Human breast cancer cell lines (MDA-MB-231 and Hs578T) and an MDA-MB-231 xenograft model in mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) could protect bile ducts against warm ischemia reperfusion injury (IRI) in liver transplantation by suppressing oxidative stress, inflammation, and apoptosis.
results_summary: SAM treatment significantly reduced bile duct injury, lowered serum markers of liver damage (ALT, ALP, DBIL), decreased oxidative stress (H2O2, MDA), improved the GSH/GSSG ratio, reduced macrophage infiltration, modulated cytokine levels (lower TNF-α, higher IL-10), and decreased apoptosis in biliary epithelial cells compared to the IRI group.
population_specificity: Male rats undergoing orthotopic autologous liver transplantation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) on long noncoding RNAs, antioxidant enzymes, and signaling pathways in diethylnitrosamine-induced hepatic cancer (HCC) in rats, focusing on its potential for chemoprevention and treatment.
results_summary: SAM downregulated ecCEBPA and UCA1 gene transcripts, ameliorated histopathological changes, attenuated PI3K/Akt protein expression, upregulated antioxidant enzymes, and reduced DNA oxidation in DEN-induced HCC. The results suggest SAM may be effective in targeting HCC-related genes via the PI3K/Akt pathway.
population_specificity: Rats with diethylnitrosamine (DEN)-induced hepatic cancer (HCC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) and Meldonium on the clinical course of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) and chronic kidney disease (CKD) stages I-II.
results_summary: SAM demonstrated powerful membrane-stabilizing effects, improved liver and kidney function, and reduced cytolysis, cholestasis, and inflammation. Combined therapy with SAM and Meldonium was superior to SAM alone, enhancing metabolic, antioxidant, and nephroprotective effects.
population_specificity: 75 patients with NASH, comorbid obesity (I degree), and CKD (stages I-II).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the chemopreventive potential of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) in inhibiting hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) development at the late precancerous stage in Mdr2-KO mice.
results_summary: Short-term SAM supplementation reduced tumor nodules, hepatocyte proliferation, and DNA methylation while increasing tumor suppressor protein expression. Long-term SAM supplementation did not affect tumor growth but increased liver DNA methylation, suggesting a bypass of cell cycle arrest.
population_specificity: Mdr2-knockout (Mdr2-KO) mice, a model of inflammation-mediated hepatocarcinogenesis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) in methylation processes and its implications for fertility, brain function, and embryonic development, alongside the effects of nutraceutical supplements like folic acid, folinic acid, and 5-MTHF.
results_summary: The study highlights SAM's critical role in methylation processes essential for cell division, gene regulation, and neuronal function, but also notes the toxicity of its byproducts (SAH and Hcy). It discusses the benefits and potential risks of nutraceutical supplements in managing methylation-related disorders, including concerns about unmetabolized folic acid (UMFA) in fetal and infant blood.
population_specificity: General discussion of methylation processes in humans, with implications for fertility, brain function, and embryonic development.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, dose proportionality, pharmacokinetics, and food effects of a novel S-adenosylmethionine formulation (MSI-195) compared to a commercial product (SAM-e Complete™).
results_summary: MSI-195 was well tolerated with a safety profile similar to SAM-e Complete™, showed 2.8-fold higher bioavailability, dose-proportional exposure, and a significant food effect delaying absorption.
population_specificity: Healthy male volunteers (first stage) and male/female volunteers (second stage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) in mediating DNA methylation and its implications for offspring health via maternal folic acid supplementation.
results_summary: The study suggests that SAM, derived from folate one-carbon metabolism, plays a critical role in fetal development and offspring health through DNA methylation, but the exact epigenetic mechanisms remain unclear. It highlights the dual effects of folic acid, with both deficiency and overload potentially impacting offspring health.
population_specificity: Pregnant women and their offspring, focusing on periconceptional and perinatal periods.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the influence of key nutrients involved in 1-carbon metabolism, including S-adenosylmethionine precursors (folate and vitamin B12), on DNA methylation in adults.
results_summary: The study found that supplementation with folic acid alone or combined with vitamin B12 significantly increased global DNA methylation, particularly in studies using liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry. Functional analysis identified 12 differentially methylated regions linked to folate and vitamin B12 biomarkers.
population_specificity: Adults (specific characteristics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of folate and S-adenosylmethionine in neurodevelopmental disorders, focusing on genetic and epigenetic influences.
results_summary: The study found that folate deficiency and gene polymorphisms in folate-related pathways correlate with neurodevelopmental disorders, suggesting S-adenosylmethionine's role in DNA and histone methylation is critical for neurodevelopment.
population_specificity: Pregnant women and individuals with neurodevelopmental disorders (e.g., autism spectrum disorder, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the mechanisms of hepatotoxicity from anticancer agents and the role of S-adenosylmethionine (SAMe) in preventing this complication.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that SAMe supplementation is effective in treating liver disease, particularly intrahepatic cholestasis, but does not provide specific results on its efficacy in preventing chemotherapy-induced liver injury.
population_specificity: Patients receiving chemotherapy (specific population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effect of 24-month folic acid supplementation on cognitive function and pathological mechanisms in mild cognitive impairment (MCI), including changes in S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) levels.
results_summary: The study found that folic acid supplementation increased SAM levels and the SAM/SAH ratio, while improving cognitive function and reducing blood levels of Aβ-related biomarkers in MCI patients.
population_specificity: 180 individuals with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the importance of achieving optimal status of folate-related B vitamins, including their interrelationships and gene-nutrient interactions, throughout the lifecycle.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the challenges in achieving optimal folate and vitamin B12 status, the impact of genetic variants like MTHFR 677C→T, and the effectiveness of mandatory folic acid fortification in reducing neural tube defects. It also notes the novel interaction between riboflavin and MTHFR in relation to blood pressure and hypertension risk.
population_specificity: General population across the lifecycle, including pregnant women, children, middle-aged, and older adults, with specific focus on sub-populations with impaired folate metabolism due to genetic characteristics.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether nutrient supplementation, including S-adenosylmethionine, could prevent or mitigate alcohol-induced organ damage.
results_summary: The study suggests that S-adenosylmethionine may help attenuate some types of alcohol-related organ damage, particularly in the liver, intestine, lung, brain, and immune system, by influencing epigenetic regulation and nutritional deficiencies.
population_specificity: Individuals with heavy alcohol consumption and associated organ damage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if methyl B12, which supports cellular methylation reactions (including S-adenosylmethionine metabolism), could improve symptoms of autism spectrum disorder (ASD).
results_summary: Methyl B12 treatment significantly improved clinician-rated ASD symptoms, correlating with enhanced methionine metabolism and cellular methylation capacity (indicated by changes in SAM/SAH ratio). No improvements were observed in parent-rated behavioral scales.
population_specificity: 50 children with ASD (mean age 5.3 years, 79% male).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of folic acid supplementation on S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) levels and its relationship with cognitive function and inflammation in Alzheimer's disease patients.
results_summary: Posttreatment, plasma SAM and SAM/SAH levels were significantly higher in the intervention group, suggesting folic acid supplementation positively influenced SAM metabolism. The study also found lower levels of Aβ 40 and inflammatory markers in the intervention group, indicating potential benefits for AD patients.
population_specificity: Patients newly diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease (age > 60 years, mild to severe, n = 121).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the role of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) in regulating the transsulfuration pathway, particularly its effects on cystathionine β-synthase (CBS) activity and H2S production during vitamin B6 deficiency.
results_summary: SAM stimulates CBS activity, maintaining cysteine production even during vitamin B6 deficiency, but H2S production capacity is reduced in deficiency states. Individual responses to vitamin B6 perturbations vary, suggesting physiological consequences in some people.
population_specificity: Humans and cultured HepG2 cells.

study_goal: The researchers examined the effects of folic acid supplementation on cognitive function and related biomarkers, including S-adenosylmethionine, in older adults with mild cognitive impairment.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in S-adenosylmethionine levels (ηp² = 0.117, p = .033) in the intervention group compared to controls, alongside cognitive benefits in specific measures like Full Scale IQ and Digit Span.
population_specificity: Chinese adults aged 65+ with mild cognitive impairment, unexposed to folic acid fortification.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether creatine supplementation (which affects SAM metabolism) lowers plasma guanidinoacetate, increases blood SAM, lowers blood SAH, and reduces plasma tHcys.
results_summary: Creatine supplementation significantly reduced plasma guanidinoacetate but did not consistently lower plasma tHcys overall, though a decrease in tHcys was observed in participants who experienced a decline in guanidinoacetate when receiving creatine plus folic acid. Folic acid alone or combined with creatine significantly reduced tHcys.
population_specificity: Bangladeshi adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the frequency of CNS abnormalities in patients with MAT1A mutations, predict their occurrence, and evaluate treatment outcomes involving methionine restriction and/or AdoMet supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that plasma methionine concentrations above 800 μM were associated with CNS abnormalities in MAT1A mutation patients. Treatment outcomes varied, with data reported on methionine restriction and AdoMet supplementation, but no definitive conclusions were drawn on optimal management.
population_specificity: 64 patients with MAT1A mutations (32 with CNS abnormalities, 32 without).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) supplementation as a therapeutic intervention for PRPS1-deficient patients, particularly those with Arts syndrome.
results_summary: SAM supplementation improved the condition of patients with Arts syndrome, suggesting it can alleviate symptoms of PRPS1 deficiency and may offer a new therapeutic approach. The study highlights the potential of SAM in addressing purine deficiencies linked to PRPS1-related disorders.
population_specificity: Patients with PRPS1-related syndromes, specifically Arts syndrome (severe PRS-I deficiency).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of folate and related B-vitamins, including their influence on S-adenosylmethionine production, in brain health across different life stages.
results_summary: The study found that folate and related B-vitamins support brain health by aiding S-adenosylmethionine production, which is crucial for neurotransmitter synthesis and DNA methylation. Supplementation reduced brain atrophy in older adults and may influence neurodevelopment in offspring.
population_specificity: Pregnant women, older adults, and general brain health across the lifecycle.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether folic acid supplementation affects intracellular concentrations of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) and its regulatory role in one-carbon metabolism.
results_summary: The study found that folic acid supplementation disrupted SAM's regulatory function on MTHFR activity in PBMCs, suggesting interference with physiological regulation of one-carbon metabolism. SAM's correlation with homocysteine was lost post-supplementation, indicating altered metabolic control.
population_specificity: 50 volunteers (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if SAM-e could improve pain and quality of life in children with FAP while assessing its safety regarding liver function and mental health.
results_summary: SAM-e showed significant improvement in self-reported pain over 2 months, with no adverse changes in liver function or mental health. The study suggests SAM-e is promising for FAP but requires larger trials for confirmation.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents (median age 14) with functional abdominal pain (FAP).
effective_dosage: Initial dose of 200 mg/day, escalated to a maximum of 1400 mg/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether folinic acid supplementation could influence SAM and SAH levels and their ratio in Rett syndrome patients, potentially improving DNA methylation processes and clinical symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that folinic acid supplementation increased plasma SAM and SAH levels but did not significantly alter CSF SAM, SAH, or their ratio, suggesting limited impact on brain methylation in Rett syndrome patients.
population_specificity: Ten female Rett syndrome patients.
study_duration: 1 year for each intervention (folinic acid and placebo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether dietary supplementation with S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) could alleviate symptoms in patients with Arts syndrome, a PRPS1-related disorder.
results_summary: The study found that SAM supplementation appeared to alleviate symptoms in Arts syndrome patients, suggesting it could compensate for PRS-I deficiency. However, the abstract does not provide detailed efficacy data or statistical significance.
population_specificity: Patients with Arts syndrome (a PRPS1-related disorder).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of creatine supplementation on homocysteine plasma levels and S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) changes after acute exercise in young athletes.
results_summary: Acute exercise decreased red blood cell SAM by 30%, but creatine supplementation did not significantly alter SAM/SAH ratios or homocysteine levels post-exercise. No changes in related metabolites (vitamin B12, folate, cysteine, methionine) were observed.
population_specificity: Twenty-three young (under-20) soccer players.
effective_dosage: 0.3 g/kg creatine or placebo tablets daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of S-adenosylmethionine as a universal methyl donor in folate and cobalamin metabolic pathways and its implications in inherited disorders.
results_summary: The study highlights that S-adenosylmethionine is crucial for DNA synthesis and methylation processes, with deficiencies in folate and cobalamin pathways leading to severe neurological and developmental issues. Early detection and B vitamin supplementation can prevent or reverse disease manifestations.
population_specificity: Individuals with inherited disorders affecting folate and cobalamin absorption, transport, or dependent enzymes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of S-adenosylmethionine (SAMe) as a supplement for treating major depressive disorder (MDD).
results_summary: The study found that SAMe supplementation is efficacious and well-tolerated in reducing depressive symptoms, with substantial evidence supporting its role in mood disorders. Compared to other folates, SAMe and L-methylfolate may be preferable due to better bioavailability and lower risk of side effects.
population_specificity: Patients with major depressive disorder (MDD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of folate in the synthesis of S-adenosylmethionine and its broader implications for epigenetics, gene regulation, and human health.
results_summary: The study highlights that folate, by contributing to S-adenosylmethionine synthesis, impacts methylation reactions critical for epigenetics and gene regulation, influencing DNA repair, genomic stability, and transcriptional output.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human health context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM-e) as a monotherapy for reducing depressive symptoms in patients with major depressive disorder.
results_summary: Oral SAM-e monotherapy reduced depressive scores in 4 out of 5 small randomized controlled trials, indicating promising efficacy for treating depression. The abstract does not detail the magnitude of improvement or adverse effects.
population_specificity: Patients with major depressive disorder (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of folic acid supplementation on plasma S-adenosylmethionine (AdoMet) levels and genomic DNA methylation in hyperhomocysteinemic subjects.
results_summary: FA supplementation increased plasma AdoMet concentrations and the AdoMet/AdoHcy ratio but had no effect on global DNA methylation levels.
population_specificity: Hyperhomocysteinemic MTHFR677TT patients with normal renal function (tHcy >30 μmol/L).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a vitamin/mineral supplement, including S-adenosylmethionine (SAM), could improve metabolic and behavioral outcomes in individuals with autism.
results_summary: The study found that SAM levels increased by 6% (p = 0.003) in the supplement group, indicating improved methylation status. These metabolic improvements correlated with significant behavioral benefits, such as reduced hyperactivity and tantrumming.
population_specificity: 141 children and adults with autism, with a subset of 53 children (ages 5-16) for metabolic assessments.
effective_dosage: Not specified (individually titrated to optimum benefit).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the influence of folate status on pregnancy health outcomes and its role in the conversion of homocysteine to methionine and subsequently to S-adenosylmethionine.
results_summary: The study highlights that improved folate status reduces risks of adverse pregnancy outcomes, fetal malformations, and maternal anemia, while inadequate folate status increases neurotoxic homocysteine levels and impairs fetal growth. Folic acid supplementation during the periconceptional period is advised to mitigate these risks.
population_specificity: Pregnant women, particularly during the periconception period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combined administration of folate and methylcobalamin affects the ratio of S-adenosylmethionine to S-adenosylhomocysteine as a transmethylation indicator in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in the S-adenosylmethionine to S-adenosylhomocysteine ratio between the folate-only and combined folate-methylcobalamin groups. However, the combined treatment improved other markers like ADMA levels and arterial stiffness.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing maintenance hemodialysis.
effective_dosage: Folate (15 mg/d) and methylcobalamin (500 µg after each hemodialysis treatment, 3 times weekly).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) and its by-product S-adenosylhomocysteine (SAH) in cardiovascular disease and related chronic conditions, focusing on mechanisms like epigenetics and oxidative stress.
results_summary: The study found that elevated homocysteine levels lead to increased SAH, a more sensitive biomarker for cardiovascular disease than homocysteine. Folate and B vitamin supplementation lowered homocysteine but not SAH levels, potentially explaining their limited efficacy in reducing vascular events.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of hyperhomocysteinemia-related diseases like cardiovascular disease, kidney disease, diabetes, and obesity).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanisms behind the exceptional longevity of Sacred lotus seeds by analyzing protein profiles and physiological responses under controlled deterioration treatment (CDT).
results_summary: The study identified 558 differentially accumulated proteins (DAPs) related to CDT resistance, with notable up-regulation in proteins linked to antioxidation, photosynthesis, and cell stability, suggesting their role in maintaining seed vigor. Histological and physiological analyses supported these proteomic findings.
population_specificity: Sacred lotus seeds (Nelumbo nucifera)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a synergistic antioxidant cocktail (Samec) containing S-adenosylmethionine could attenuate the development of meal-induced insulin resistance (AMIS) and associated metabolic dysfunctions in aging rats, particularly those on a sucrose-supplemented diet.
results_summary: Samec, which includes S-adenosylmethionine, significantly attenuated the development of AMIS and associated metabolic dysfunctions (hyperglycemia, hyperinsulinemia, hyperlipidemia, and adiposity) in both normal aging rats and those on a sucrose-supplemented diet. The cocktail fully compensated for the negative metabolic effects of the sucrose supplement.
population_specificity: Aging rats (up to one year of age)
study_duration: Not specified (study followed rats up to one year of age)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different modification methods (PG, HMT, EP) on the composition, functional properties, and estimated glycemic index (eGI) of native lotus seed flour (N-LSF).
results_summary: HMT and EP increased amylose and resistant starch (RS) contents, leading to low eGI values (<50), making them suitable for diabetes patients or health-conscious individuals. PG increased rapid digestible starch (RDS) and had a medium eGI (60), making it less suitable for these populations.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or general population implied)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether B-vitamin supplementation (including folate, B12, and B6) affects plasma S-adenosylmethionine (AdoMet) and S-adenosylhomocysteine (AdoHcy) concentrations in older adults with elevated homocysteine.
results_summary: B-vitamin supplementation significantly lowered plasma homocysteine but had no significant effect on plasma AdoMet or AdoHcy concentrations or the AdoMet:AdoHcy ratio. This suggests that B-vitamins may not influence these biomarkers despite reducing homocysteine.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults (≥65 years) with elevated homocysteine (>13 μmol/L).
effective_dosage: Daily supplement containing folate (1 mg), vitamin B12 (500 μg), and vitamin B6 (10 mg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant activity and safety of hydro alcoholic extract of Nelumbo nucifera seeds (HANN) using in vitro and in vivo models.
results_summary: HANN demonstrated strong free radical scavenging activity, with low IC50 values in DPPH and nitric oxide assays, outperforming the standard rutin. In vivo, HANN administration significantly increased SOD and catalase levels while reducing TBARS in liver and kidney tissues, comparable to Vitamin E.
population_specificity: Swiss Albino mice (acute toxicity) and Wistar rats (antioxidant effects).
effective_dosage: 100 and 200 mg/kg body weight (rats); up to 1,000 mg/kg (mice).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the heat tolerance and physiological responses of Sacred lotus seeds compared to maize seeds under high-temperature conditions.
results_summary: Sacred lotus seeds demonstrated exceptional heat tolerance, maintaining germination and structural integrity at 100°C for up to 12 hours, while maize seeds failed within minutes. Enzymatic activities (SOD, GR, CAT, APX, DHAR) in lotus seeds showed adaptive responses to heat stress, whereas maize seeds exhibited rapid degradation.
population_specificity: Sacred lotus (Nelumbo nucifera Gaertn. 'Tielian') seeds and maize (Zea mays L. 'Huangbaogu') seeds.
study_duration: Treatment durations ranged from minutes to 24 hours at 100°C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) supplementation could alleviate symptoms in patients with PRPS1-related disorders by replenishing purine nucleotides.
results_summary: Preliminary results showed improvement in two Arts syndrome patients after SAM supplementation, suggesting potential benefits for symptom alleviation in PRPS1 spectrum diseases.
population_specificity: Patients with PRPS1-related disorders (specifically Arts syndrome in the preliminary results).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the aphrodisiac potential and safety profile of Safed Musli extract on the reproductive system, particularly its effects on sexual behavior and sperm parameters.
results_summary: Safed Musli enhanced sexual vigor and libido in male rats up to 28 days and increased sperm count and motility after 54 days, though it also slightly increased sperm abnormality (less than 10%).
population_specificity: Wistar albino rats (male and female, with a focus on male reproductive effects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether C. borivilianum (Safed Musli) root extract could prevent sperm impairment and oxidative stress in diabetic rats.
results_summary: The extract improved sperm count, motility, viability, and antioxidant levels while reducing oxidative stress, apoptosis, and abnormal sperm in diabetic rats. It also lowered blood glucose and HbA1c levels, suggesting potential benefits for diabetic reproductive health.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic male rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a nutriceutical formulation containing S-adenosylmethionine improves cognitive performance in adults without dementia.
results_summary: Participants receiving the nutriceutical formulation showed statistically and clinically significant improvements in cognitive tests, with benefits reversing upon withdrawal and reappearing upon resumption. Elderly participants (≥74 years) showed less improvement, possibly due to absorption or nutritional deficiencies.
population_specificity: Adults of both genders without dementia.
study_duration: Initial trial period followed by a 3-month open-label extension; additional 6-month and 2-week open-label trials mentioned.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of maternal safflower oil consumption on reflex maturation, memory, and hippocampal oxidative stress in offspring.
results_summary: Safflower oil delayed reflex maturation but improved memory (novel object recognition) and enhanced antioxidant defenses (reduced lipid peroxidation, increased SOD, CAT, GST, and GSH levels) in offspring.
population_specificity: Pregnant and lactating rats and their offspring.
effective_dosage: Not specified (normolipidic diet with safflower oil as lipid source).
study_duration: From the 14th day of gestation through lactation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the spermatogenesis and androgenesis augmentative effects of Chlorophytum borivilianum (Safed Musli) root extract in counteracting cyproterone acetate-induced subfertility in male rats.
results_summary: The study found that Safed Musli root extract improved male reproductive potential by enhancing oxidative defense and maintaining testicular apoptosis homeostasis, effectively reversing the negative effects of cyproterone acetate on semen quality and fertility.
population_specificity: Male Wistar strain albino rats with induced subfertility.
effective_dosage: 400 mg/kg twice daily (with a 20-minute interval from cyproterone acetate administration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether safflower oil body (SOB) nanoparticles loaded with hFGF10 could effectively target hair follicles and accelerate hair regeneration in androgenetic alopecia (AGA) with minimal adverse effects.
results_summary: SOB-hFGF10 nanoparticles showed preferential penetration into hair follicles, significantly improved hair regeneration in AGA mice, and reduced DHT-induced inflammatory markers (TNF-α, IL-1β, IL-6) without significant toxicity.
population_specificity: Male mice with androgenetic alopecia (AGA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of safflower oil as a natural therapy for postoperative pain by comparing its analgesic and anti-inflammatory effects to benzydamine HCl and naproxen sodium.
results_summary: Safflower oil at 300 mg/kg showed central spinal analgesic efficacy comparable to naproxen sodium and peripheral analgesic effects at both 100 and 300 mg/kg. It also demonstrated significant anti-inflammatory effects, though naproxen sodium showed the most marked edema inhibition.
population_specificity: Healthy adult female Wistar albino rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize lncRNA expression in the bovine mammary gland and infer their functions in response to dietary supplementation with 5% safflower oil (SFO).
results_summary: The study identified 21 differentially expressed lncRNAs in response to SFO, with potential roles in immune function, nucleic acid metabolism, and signaling pathways like Notch and TGF-β. Six genes were identified as potential cis targets of these lncRNAs.
population_specificity: Twelve mid-lactation cows (six per treatment group).
study_duration: 28-day treatment period following a 28-day control period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of safflower oil (SO) and virgin coconut oil (VCO) on body composition and cardiovascular risk factors in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Safflower oil did not significantly alter lipid values, showing a neutral effect on TC/HDL ratio. No adverse effects were reported for SO, unlike VCO, which caused adverse reactions in one participant.
population_specificity: Caucasian postmenopausal women (aged 58.8 ± 3.7 years) living in the United States.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the expression pattern of miRNAs in bovine mammary glands following dietary supplementation with 5% safflower oil and its impact on milk fat composition.
results_summary: Safflower oil supplementation significantly decreased milk fat percentage and specific saturated fatty acids while increasing certain unsaturated fatty acids. It also affected the expression of 22 miRNAs, with seven core miRNAs identified as regulators of lipid metabolism pathways.
population_specificity: Mid-lactation Canadian Holstein dairy cows (12 per treatment group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of supplemental feeding with safflower oil (SFO) on the bovine mammary gland transcriptome and milk fatty acid composition.
results_summary: Safflower oil supplementation decreased milk saturated fatty acids (SFAs) and increased beneficial fatty acids (FAs), such as C18:1n11t, CLA:10t12c, and C20:3n3, while also reducing milk fat percentage. It differentially regulated 199 genes, with potential implications for milk fat traits and lipid metabolism.
population_specificity: Mid-lactation Holstein cows

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the fatty acid composition and oil quality of safflower for sustainable biodiesel feedstock production by testing the effects of Azospirillum and Azotobacter inoculation, alone and combined with reduced NP fertilizers.
results_summary: The study found that Azospirillum supplemented with a quarter dose of NP fertilizers significantly improved monounsaturated fatty acids (oleic acid) and reduced polyunsaturated fatty acids, while combined applications of Azotobacter and Azospirillum with reduced NP doses improved oil quality attributes linked to better biodiesel yield.
population_specificity: Safflower cultivars Thori and Saif-32 under field conditions.
effective_dosage: Quarter and half doses of NP fertilizers combined with Azospirillum and Azotobacter.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the in vitro synergistic efficacy of safflower oil, conjugated linoleic acid (CLA), oleic acid (OLA), and taxol (Tax) on cytotoxicity in human prostate cancer (PC3) cells.
results_summary: The study found that safflower oil's efficacy was not explicitly detailed, but OLA-Tax and CLA-Tax combinations showed enhanced cytotoxicity on PC3 cells, while safflower oil's specific effects were not highlighted.
population_specificity: Human prostate cancer (PC3) cell line.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of high oleic safflower oil (HOSF) as an adjuvant therapy in improving outcomes for children with HPV-induced laryngeal papillomatosis (LP) when used alongside surgery.
results_summary: HOSF showed milder effects compared to CLA but contributed to remission in children with mildly/moderately aggressive papillomatosis. No harmful effects were observed, and some children with low total scores and reduced infections recovered after the trial.
population_specificity: Children aged 4 to 12 years with HPV-induced laryngeal papillomatosis.
study_duration: 8 weeks per treatment (with a 6-week washout period between treatments).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of safflower oil (SAF) on glycemia, blood lipids, and inflammation in post-menopausal, obese women with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: SAF significantly decreased HbA1c and C-reactive protein, increased QUICKI and HDL cholesterol, with effects observed after 12-16 weeks of supplementation.
population_specificity: Post-menopausal, obese women with type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate dietary strategies, including safflower oil supplementation, to increase the concentration of conjugated linoleic acid (CLA) in bovine milk fat.
results_summary: Safflower oil significantly increased CLA levels in milk fat, particularly when combined with monensin. Vitamin E partially prevented milk fat depression but did not affect CLA concentration.
population_specificity: Holstein cows

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of safflower oil (SAF) and conjugated linoleic acid (CLA) on body weight, composition, and metabolic outcomes in obese postmenopausal women with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Safflower oil had no effect on BMI or total adipose mass but reduced trunk adipose mass and increased lean mass. It also significantly lowered fasting glucose and increased adiponectin levels.
population_specificity: Obese postmenopausal women with type 2 diabetes.
study_duration: Two 16-week diet periods separated by a 4-week washout (total 36 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if increasing dietary safflower oil levels would alter unsaturated fat (especially CLA) and tocopherol content in lamb, as well as its impact on animal performance, carcass characteristics, and meat color stability.
results_summary: Increasing safflower oil supplementation (up to 6% of the diet) raised linoleic acid and CLA levels in lamb muscle tissue without affecting growth performance, carcass characteristics, or meat color stability. Tocopherol content remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Targhee x Rambouillet wethers (lambs)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how boron deprivation and dietary fat sources (safflower oil vs. fish oil) influence rat behavior and brain composition.
results_summary: Boron-deficient rats fed safflower oil showed reduced activity compared to boron-adequate rats, while fish oil attenuated this effect. Safflower oil increased plasma 8-iso-PGF2alpha, suggesting oxidative stress, and interacted with boron deprivation to affect behavior and brain mineral composition.
population_specificity: Female rats and their male offspring.
effective_dosage: 75 g/kg safflower oil in the diet.
study_duration: From gestation through 21 weeks of age (post-weaning).
interactions: Interaction noted between boron deprivation and dietary fat sources (safflower oil vs. fish oil).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of safflower oil (SO) with other dietary oils on carnitine status and ethanol metabolism in rats.
results_summary: Safflower oil (SO) showed faster ethanol metabolism compared to fish oil (FO) and palm oil (PO), but its effects on carnitine species varied before and after dietary treatment and ethanol administration. The study did not find significant adverse effects specific to SO.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats (300 g body weight, n=6 per group).
effective_dosage: Not specified (semisynthetic diet containing SO as the fat source).
study_duration: Not specified (before and after dietary treatment and acute ethanol administration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of high-linoleate safflower oil supplementation on duodenal and ileal fatty acid flows, ruminal fermentation, and nutrient digestion in sheep fed an 80% concentrate diet.
results_summary: Increased dietary safflower oil raised fatty acid intake and duodenal flow of esterified fatty acids, particularly 18:2c-9,c-12, without significantly affecting digestibility of OM, NDF, or N. Apparent small intestinal absorption of 18:2c-9,c-12 and 18:2c-9,t-11 improved with higher oil supplementation.
population_specificity: Four crossbred wethers (sheep) with an average body weight of 44.3 ± 15.7 kg.
effective_dosage: 0%, 3%, 6%, and 9% of dry matter (DM) infused intraruminally.
study_duration: 14 days of dietary adaptation followed by 4 days of sampling.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether consuming triacylglycerol-esterified linoleic acid (LA) from safflower oil increases plasma concentrations of conjugated linoleic acid (CLA) in humans.
results_summary: The study found that while safflower oil significantly increased LA intake, it did not affect plasma CLA concentrations. However, it significantly lowered plasma total cholesterol and LDL-cholesterol levels.
population_specificity: Six men and six women.
effective_dosage: 21 g safflower oil daily (providing 16 g LA/d).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the modifying effects of dietary conjugated fatty acids from safflower oil (CFA-S) on major organs, particularly its potential as a chemopreventor of mammary carcinogenesis in a two-stage carcinogenesis model.
results_summary: CFA-S significantly reduced the incidence and multiplicity of mammary carcinomas but increased urinary bladder hyperplasia at the 1% dose. No clear dose-response relationship was observed for mammary carcinogenesis prevention.
population_specificity: Female F344 rats in a post-initiation stage of a two-stage carcinogenesis model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of safflower oil (rich in n-6 linoleic acid) versus perilla oil (rich in n-3 alpha-linolenic acid) on DMBA- and DMH-induced mammary gland and colon carcinogenesis in rats.
results_summary: Safflower oil was associated with higher colon tumor incidence (47.4%) compared to perilla oil (18.2%) and showed no significant advantage in reducing mammary tumors or nephroblastomas.
population_specificity: Female Sprague-Dawley rats, 5 weeks old.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether safflower oil administration protected against embryotoxicity caused by snakeweed ingestion during pregnancy and assessed its impact on fecundity in offspring.
results_summary: Safflower oil did not significantly differ from normal saline in protecting against snakeweed-induced reproductive effects, with dams producing healthy offspring regardless of treatment. No fertility impairment was observed in female offspring.
population_specificity: Primiparous female Sprague-Dawley rats and their offspring.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cutaneously applied safflower oil could prevent essential fatty acid deficiency (EFAD) in patients on home parenteral nutrition (HPN) after bowel resection.
results_summary: Cutaneous safflower oil improved plasma fatty acid profiles, reversing declines in linoleic and arachidonic acid and reducing the triene:tetraene ratio. However, the oral phase was poorly completed, and tissue store adequacy and liver function monitoring remain unresolved.
population_specificity: Patients with massive bowel resection on HPN supplemented with IV fat emulsions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether safflower oil could correct essential fatty acid deficiencies in cystic fibrosis patients.
results_summary: Safflower oil treatment (1 g/kg/day) failed to correct the aberrant fatty acid patterns in cystic fibrosis patients, suggesting impaired linoleate-to-arachidonate conversion and absorption issues.
population_specificity: Cystic fibrosis patients compared to random hospitalized patients of the same age groups and both sexes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of two safflower oil emulsions with differing alpha-linolenic acid content on neonates requiring total parenteral nutrition.
results_summary: Both emulsions prevented or corrected essential fatty acid deficiency without significant clinical differences, though the high alpha-linolenic acid group showed increased levels of alpha-linolenic acid and eicosapentaenoic acid. Docosahexaenoic acid decreased in both groups, and arachidonic acid levels dropped while linoleic to arachidonic acid ratios rose.
population_specificity: Neonates requiring total parenteral nutrition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of safflower oil emulsion on essential fatty acid status, plasma triglycerides, and plasma free fatty acids in preterm infants during parenteral nutrition.
results_summary: Essential fatty acid status remained normal in both dosage groups, but higher lipid intake led to greater changes in plasma triglycerides and more frequent hypertriglyceridemia. Free fatty acid levels did not differ between groups but varied by gestational age, with no unsafe FFA/albumin ratios observed.
population_specificity: Preterm infants (gestational age <32 weeks and 32-34 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cutaneous application of safflower oil could reverse biochemical manifestations of essential fatty acid (EFA) deficiency in rats.
results_summary: The study found that safflower oil application increased linoleic and arachidonic acid levels while decreasing eicosatrienoic acid in plasma and erythrocyte phospholipids, effectively reversing EFA deficiency markers. The effects were consistent across plasma fractions, though some changes were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: EFA-deficient rats
effective_dosage: Approximately 185 mg of safflower oil (140 mg linoleic acid) applied daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of a 10% safflower oil emulsion in treating or preventing essential fatty acid deficiency in surgical patients requiring total parenteral nutrition.
results_summary: The study found no significant adverse effects or clinically significant deviations in laboratory parameters, and all three dosage regimens effectively treated or prevented essential fatty acid deficiency, as evidenced by normalized triene/tetraene ratios.
population_specificity: 15 surgical patients requiring total parenteral nutrition for two to four weeks.
effective_dosage: Group I: 4% of calories as linoleate daily; Group II: 4% of calories as linoleate every other day; Group III: 8% of calories every other day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential link between safflower oil consumption and acute liver failure (ALF) in patients using it for weight loss.
results_summary: The study reported three cases of ALF associated with safflower oil use, leading to liver transplantation in all patients, with two surviving and one dying post-procedure. The findings suggest safflower oil may pose a risk for severe liver damage when used for weight loss.
population_specificity: Patients with acute liver failure and a history of safflower oil consumption for weight loss.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-oleic safflower oil versus omega-3 fatty acids on plasma phospholipid fatty acid (PLFA) concentrations in HIV and HHV8 infected patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in plasma PLFA concentrations or total cholesterol in the safflower oil group, indicating it did not alter fatty acid profiles. Both relative and absolute concentration measurements were effective for assessing changes.
population_specificity: 66 HIV and HHV8 infected patients in Uganda.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the medicinal effects of saffron and its compounds, particularly their mechanisms of action via the Nrf2 signaling pathway, in treating diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that saffron and its components have potential therapeutic effects for diabetes due to their ability to modulate the Nrf2 signaling pathway, reducing oxidative damage and inflammation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general diabetic environment implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of a saffron-based supplement (combined with ashwagandha, tryptophan, and vitamin B6) in improving anxiety and health-related quality of life.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant improvement in anxiety (measured by HARS) and a modest but significant improvement in health-related quality of life after 12 weeks of supplementation. However, no significant changes were observed during the COVID-19 lockdown period.
population_specificity: Female employees (mean age 45.0 years) reporting mild to moderate anxiety.
effective_dosage: Two tablets daily (specific saffron dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the protective effects of Saffron Repron® in slowing retinal degeneration in a mouse model of retinitis pigmentosa (RP).
results_summary: Chronic saffron treatment slowed retinal damage progression, preserved retinal neuron function and morphology, and modulated epigenetic pathways linked to neuroinflammation, suggesting acquired resilience.
population_specificity: Pregnant female mice and their weaned pups (mouse model of RP).
study_duration: 120 days (administered to pregnant females and continued in weaned pups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy and safety of saffron extract alone and in combination with scutellaria extract for mood regulation in individuals with mild-to-moderate depressive symptoms.
results_summary: Saffron extract demonstrated beneficial effects on depressive and anxious symptoms and improved sleep quality. The combination with scutellaria showed synergistic effects, enhancing mood regulation and emotional well-being compared to placebo.
population_specificity: 180 participants with mild-to-moderate depressive symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the detoxification effect of saffron petal extracts (PCSE) on acetaminophen-induced liver injury in mice and explore its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: PCSE improved survival rates, reduced liver injury markers (ALT, AST), lowered pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6), and mitigated oxidative stress and apoptosis in liver cells by activating the Nrf2/HO-1 signaling pathway.
population_specificity: Mice with acetaminophen-induced acute liver injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the therapeutic potential of saffron extract in treating atopic dermatitis (AD), focusing on its mechanisms and potential interventions.
results_summary: Saffron extracts like crocin, crocetin, and safranal showed promising anti-inflammatory, immunomodulatory, and skin barrier repair effects in AD treatment, offering safer and more effective alternatives to conventional therapies.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate saffron's potential role in treating traumatic brain injury (TBI) by modulating inflammatory, apoptotic, and oxidative stress pathways.
results_summary: Saffron demonstrated modulation of key signaling pathways (NF-kB, NLRP3, Nrf2, HO-1, Bcl2, Bax) and reduced inflammation, apoptosis, and oxidative stress in TBI models, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits. However, clinical trials are needed to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: Preclinical studies (in-vitro and in-vivo models of TBI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Trichoderma harzianum Bi, nano-TiO2, and magnetic field treatments on saffron cormlet production under high-temperature stress conditions.
results_summary: Combined T. harzianum and 250 μl l-1 nano-TiO2 treatment significantly enhanced cormlet weight (68.9% increase) and improved key metabolites like starch, GABA, and myoinositol. Magnetic field exposure increased cormlet numbers but reduced individual weights by 20%.
population_specificity: Saffron corms (Crocus sativus L.) grown under high-temperature greenhouse conditions (25/15 °C day/night).
effective_dosage: T. harzianum (100% v/v medium enrichment), nano-TiO2 (250 μl l-1), magnetic field (60 militesla, 30-min constant exposure).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether saffron extract has antidepressant and anti-anhedonic effects in preclinical models and patients with unipolar or bipolar depression.
results_summary: Saffron administration restored motivation and reward reactivity in anhedonic rats, likely by modulating dopaminergic transmission and BDNF-TrkB signaling. In depressed patients, an 8-week saffron add-on therapy improved depressive symptoms and significantly reduced anhedonia.
population_specificity: Rats in preclinical models and patients diagnosed with unipolar or bipolar depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of saffron ethanolic extract on cataractous lens changes in atherosclerotic-induced New Zealand white rabbits.
results_summary: Saffron treatment reduced cataract severity (from grade 2 to grade 1), decreased vacuoles and homogenized areas, and improved lens fiber structure. The bioactive components crocin, crocetin, and phytochemical compounds likely contributed to these positive effects.
population_specificity: Atherosclerotic-induced New Zealand white rabbits
study_duration: 16 weeks (including 8 weeks of high-cholesterol diet and subsequent saffron treatment)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the in vitro induction of stigma-like structures (SLSs) from various explants of the Ghaen ecotype saffron flower and assess their similarity to natural saffron in terms of key metabolites.
results_summary: The study found that ovary explants were most effective for inducing SLSs, with the B5 medium enriched with BAP and NAA being optimal. SLSs contained crocin, picrocrocin, and safranal but at significantly lower concentrations than natural saffron.
population_specificity: In vitro explants of the Ghaen ecotype saffron flower.
effective_dosage: B5 medium supplemented with 5-10 mg/L BAP and 5-10 mg/L NAA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the physiological and phytochemical responses of saffron to potassium (K), phosphorus (P), and iron-zinc (Fe-Zn) biofertilizers over two consecutive years.
results_summary: The K + Fe-Zn treatment significantly improved saffron's quantitative traits (flower count, duration, stigma dry weight, flowering rate) and qualitative traits (phenolic content, anthocyanin, crocin, picrocrocin, safranal) compared to the control group. The most pronounced effects were observed in the second year of application.
population_specificity: Saffron plants cultivated in mineral-fortified soils.
effective_dosage: Biofertilizers applied at 0.5 L per hectare by fertigation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different LED light treatments (white, red, blue) affect saffron growth, flowering, and metabolite accumulation in the stigma.
results_summary: Supplemental white and red lights promoted dry mass accumulation in the stigma, with white light yielding optimal appearance. White light also promoted flowering, while blue light delayed it. Blue light increased crocin-1 and crocin-3, whereas red light increased crocin-2.
population_specificity: Indoor-cultivated saffron (Crocus sativus L.) plants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of saffron extract on late-onset hypogonadism (LOH) using an aging mouse model and Leydig cells, focusing on its potential mechanisms and therapeutic targets.
results_summary: Saffron extract modulated the PI3K-Akt-Nrf2 signaling pathway, improved Leydig cell resistance to oxidative stress, reduced apoptosis, and alleviated age-related declines in serum testosterone and testicular function.
population_specificity: Aging mice induced with D-galactose and Leydig cells.
effective_dosage: Varying concentrations (specific amounts not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether saffron could improve negative symptoms in chronic schizophrenia patients when used alongside risperidone.
results_summary: Saffron significantly reduced negative symptoms, general psychopathology, and total PANSS scores compared to placebo, with greater improvements at weeks 4 and 8. It was well-tolerated with no significant differences in adverse effects or depression scores between groups.
population_specificity: Clinically stable chronic schizophrenic outpatients (n=56).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of saffron or crocin intake on oxidative stress, inflammation, and renal/liver function parameters in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: Saffron supplementation significantly reduced levels of tumor necrosis factor-α, interleukin-6, and malondialdehyde, indicating improved oxidative stress and inflammation. Subgroup analyses showed that ≥100 mg/day of saffron further reduced IL-6 and MDA levels, and a treatment period of <60 days lowered alanine transaminase levels.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
study_duration: Treatment periods varied, with some interventions lasting <60 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of saffron petal extract on egg quality, blood metabolites, and odorous gas emissions in laying hens.
results_summary: Saffron petal extract at 80 ppm significantly reduced yolk and serum cholesterol, decreased blood glucose and triglycerides, and lowered fecal ammonia emissions, while not affecting egg protein, fat, ash content, or feed intake.
population_specificity: 200 Hy-line W36 laying hens aged 39 weeks
effective_dosage: 40, 60, or 80 ppm hydroalcoholic saffron petal extract

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of ultrasound treatment on saffron corms during different growth stages, focusing on flowering efficiency, morphological properties, microbial population, and secondary metabolite concentrations.
results_summary: Ultrasound treatment for 15-30 minutes increased flowering efficiency and crocin content but reduced it at 60 minutes. Prolonged sonication decreased picrocrocin and safranal levels while reducing microbial populations and enhancing corm resistance.
population_specificity: Saffron (Crocus sativus L.) plants
study_duration: Applied during flower induction and flower initiation stages

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and meta-analyze the effects of saffron and its extract on cardiometabolic indicators in diabetic and prediabetic overweight patients.
results_summary: Saffron supplementation significantly improved FBS, HbA1C, TG, SBP, and AST levels in T2DM patients but showed no significant effects on insulin secretion, HOMA, TC, HDL, LDL, TNF-α, creatinine, or BUN.
population_specificity: Overweight patients with diabetes or prediabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of saffron petal extract, alone or combined with other adsorbents, in mitigating the negative impacts of aflatoxin B1 and ochratoxin A in broiler chickens.
results_summary: Saffron petal extract, especially when combined with yeast cell wall and processed bentonite, improved carcass weights, reduced liver enzyme concentrations, and enhanced small intestine morphology in toxin-exposed chickens. The study concluded that saffron petal extract can effectively modulate diets contaminated with these toxins.
population_specificity: One-day-old Ross 308 broiler chickens
effective_dosage: 750 mg/kg saffron petal extract, 0.1% yeast cell wall extract, and 1% processed bentonite

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary supplementation with Saffron improves growth performance, immune response, and disease resistance in Nile tilapia against Aeromonas hydrophila.
results_summary: Saffron supplementation, especially at 1.5 g/kg, enhanced weight gain, immune markers (lysozyme activity, IgM), and tissue regeneration in gills, liver, and spleen. It also improved survival rates and disease resistance against A. hydrophila.
population_specificity: Nile tilapia (fish)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the mechanistic, pre-clinical, and clinical evidence of saffron's effects, safety, and tolerability in treating age-related macular degeneration (ARMD).
results_summary: Saffron and its active compounds improved visual function and delayed ARMD progression, with benefits observed in both dry and wet forms. The supplement was found to be safe and well tolerated, with effects maintained during follow-up periods.
population_specificity: Individuals with age-related macular degeneration (ARMD).
effective_dosage: 20-50 mg of saffron or 5-15 mg of crocin daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Saffron Petal Extract (SPE) could attenuate oxidative stress and inflammation in a simulated human intestinal microenvironment, specifically targeting the NF-κB pathway.
results_summary: SPE significantly reduced oxidative stress and inflammation by downregulating pro-inflammatory mediators (iNOS, COX-2, IL-1β, IL-6) via modulation of the NF-κB pathway, suggesting potential as a complementary therapeutic for IBD.
population_specificity: In vitro co-culture system of Caco-2 cells and PMA-differentiated THP-1 macrophages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of serotonin growth regulator on morphophysiological and biochemical characteristics of saffron under water stress conditions.
results_summary: Water stress negatively impacted saffron's growth and photosynthetic parameters, while exogenous serotonin application (especially root treatment) improved plant growth by activating antioxidant systems, enhancing resistance to water stress.
population_specificity: Saffron plants under water stress conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of cold plasma pre-treatment in preserving saffron's color integrity and reducing microbial contamination while maintaining its physicochemical attributes.
results_summary: Cold plasma treatment, particularly in an argon atmosphere, significantly reduced microbial load (by 0.9 logarithmic cycles) with minimal impact on color, taste, aroma, and antioxidant properties (decreases of 0.5%, 0.5%, 0.08%, and 0.64%, respectively). No Escherichia coli, mold, or yeast were detected in treated samples.
population_specificity: Dried saffron stigma (agricultural commodity).
effective_dosage: Not specified (process parameters: 1-10 min exposure, 40-100 W power).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a sensitive and selective electrochemical sensor using saffron-based copper nanoflowers (CuNFs) for detecting the proteasome inhibitor bortezomib (BOR).
results_summary: The study demonstrated that saffron-based CuNFs enhanced the sensor's sensitivity and selectivity, achieving detection limits in the femtomolar range (29 fM LOD) with high repeatability and reproducibility (0.87%-2.17%). The sensor performed reliably in human serum samples and showed unique selectivity against BOR metabolites.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how pre-sowing treatments (cold plasma, vacuum, electromagnetic field) affect the growth, yield, and secondary metabolite content of saffron (Crocus sativus).
results_summary: Cold plasma negatively impacted plant growth and metabolite content, while electromagnetic field (EMF) treatment significantly increased secondary metabolite production in saffron stigmas, including crocins and picrocrocin. Vacuum improved germination uniformity but had minimal effects on stigma compounds.
population_specificity: Crocus sativus (saffron) plants
effective_dosage: Not specified (pre-sowing treatments: CP 3 and 5 min, vacuum 3 min, EMF 5 min)
study_duration: Not specified (duration of plant growth until harvest)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate saffron's potential as an alternative therapy for mild to moderate depression, comparing its efficacy and safety to standard medications.
results_summary: Saffron demonstrated comparable effectiveness to standard antidepressants in treating mild to moderate depression, with fewer side effects. Its components (crocin, crocetin, safranal) showed antidepressant effects through neurotransmitter regulation, anti-inflammatory properties, and neuroprotection.
population_specificity: Individuals with mild to moderate depression (human and animal studies referenced).
interactions: Potential drug interactions at higher therapeutic doses, requiring careful monitoring.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of saffron's active compounds on the efficacy of immunotherapy for colorectal cancer, focusing on its anti-cancer mechanisms.
results_summary: Saffron's active components, particularly crocin and safranal, suppressed colorectal cancer cell proliferation, reduced inflammatory factors, and improved the tumor immunological microenvironment via the IL-17 signaling pathway, enhancing immunotherapy efficacy.
population_specificity: In vitro (CT26 and HCT116 cells) and in vivo (mice with induced colorectal cancer) models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine how crocin (a component of saffron) affected mitochondrial regulators (Drp1, Pgc1α, Nrf1, and Mfn2) in the lung tissue of ovalbumin-sensitized mice.
results_summary: Crocin (30 mg/kg and 60 mg/kg) and dexamethasone significantly reduced inflammatory cells and restored mitochondrial dynamics in ovalbumin-sensitized mice, reversing elevated Drp1, Pgc1α, and Nrf1 levels and increasing Mfn2 expression.
population_specificity: Male BALB/C mice sensitized with ovalbumin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the preclinical evidence and potential mechanisms of saffron and its constituents in an animal model of ovalbumin-induced asthma.
results_summary: Saffron and its components significantly reduced inflammatory markers (e.g., IL-4, IL-5, IL-13, IgE) and improved pulmonary function by modulating ER stress markers and miRNAs pathways. The meta-analysis demonstrated consistent anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and immunomodulatory effects.
population_specificity: Animal model (536 animals) with ovalbumin-induced asthma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the biological effects of saffron petal extract on cell survival, migration, angiogenesis, and wound healing in diabetic mice.
results_summary: The study found that saffron petal extract promoted cell viability, migration, and angiogenesis, upregulated COL1A1 and VEGF expression, and accelerated wound closure in diabetic mice compared to controls.
population_specificity: Human dermal fibroblasts (HDFs), human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs), and diabetic mice.
